Degeneracy}}


In quantum mechanics, a branch of physics, two or more different states of a
system are said to be 'degenerate' if they are all at the same energy level. It
is represented mathematically by the Hamiltonian for the system having more than
one linearly independent eigenstate with the same eigenvalue. Conversely, an
energy level is said to be degenerate if it contains two or more different
states. The number of different states at a particular energy level is called
the level's degeneracy, and this phenomenon is generally known as a 'quantum
degeneracy'.

From the perspective of quantum statistical mechanics, several degenerate states
at the same level are all equally probable of being filled.
